Articles.Content:
> 
> 
> 6 minutes ago, MrMeeb said:
> 
> 
> Is that just the Mk3 cargo bay? It looks too round! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif ":D")
> 

I figured this out a while ago (actually, maybe I read about it somewhere) when I was trying to find a prettier replacement for stock 3.75m tanks.  Basically, you attach a mk3 tank where you want, then you attach a mk3 cargo bay, rotated 90 degrees, of the same length to the end of the tank.  Then you offset the cargo bay along the axis of the tank, so they overlap.  There is some z-fighting, so I offset the cargo bay down the smallest amount possible.

Looks like the counterweight idea worked.

![G2XB03m.png](http://i.imgur.com/G2XB03m.png)

I should probably set up an action group to cut all the parachutes, they made it hard to judge my deceleration and kept swinging all over the place.

![SVrbQPt.png](http://i.imgur.com/SVrbQPt.png)

It's sad that this is the best landing I've accomplished so far. Two of the landing struts \*overstressed\* when I tried to deploy them, and the engines managed to overheat a cubic strut or two. the other two legs probably couldn't bear the whole weight of the lander and \*overstressed\*. When I tried to deploy the SPR the game rewarded me for my achievement by crashing.

Yeah, in case you didn't notice, I stole the DAV design from [@Mad Rocket Scientist](%7B___base_url___%7D/index.php?/profile/139256-mad-rocket-scientist/). Sorry, but it was such a clever idea!

I'm glad you sorted the flipping issue! Yup, you need to cut those chutes for a propulsive landing. Just set <abbr title="Stability Augmentation System">sas</abbr> to retrograde with the focus on that DAV pod or that docking port and then just feather the throttle. You can land at very low speed then. Just don't go below 1m/s as it will deactivate the retrograde hold.

 Are your descent engines separate from the DAV engines?

But it's your pack man and I am happy to see people making it in different ways!

 I just had a thought, Kerbals cannot get out of your fairing DAV pod.. Is that what the extra pod I saw is for? But it's so fun to climb directly into the pod! Maybe you can expose the door a little so they can still do that?

Can i give you some constructive criticism? I will assume so. The pod looks too big for the DAV/MAV and is set too high. In the proposed lander the pod is quite small compared to the rest of the lander. What reference pics are you working off?
I am going to start working on building Ares I & Orion CEV today. So expect some pictures very soon.

> 
> 
> 1 hour ago, Majorjim said:
> 
> 
> What reference pics are you working off?
> 

None, really. My main goal here is to make something that works, and my secondary one is to make it easy to use. I think making it look exactly like the concept images is only my #3 priority. Besides, the designs would likely have changed drastically before they went into production, so I think some differences will be acceptable. As an example of just how much things can change, allow me to link you to [a photo of the original concept for the Apollo Lunar Module from 1963](http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/images/378812main_if_model_original_full_full.jpg).

But yeah, I think maybe command seats would be a better option for the DAV, and I will consider making it somewhat smaller. I might try and integrate the Descent engines and ascent Engines too, although I'm not sure about that just yet.

I have pictures! Well, a picture. So here is my Orion CEV! Hopefully the links work.

![zt596Bg.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/zt596Bg.jpg) 

Note that in the original Orion CEV concepts, the service module was not going to be a derivative of the automated transfer vehicle's service module. That is the reason why the service module is bigger, and the solar panels are different.

 ![eGgreup.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/eGgreup.jpg) 

  #SpaceShuttleLivesMatter

> 2 hours ago, The\_Shortline\_Gamer said:
> 
> 
> -snip-
> 

I like that version of Altair better, that's what I modeled my LV-3A 'Bullfrog' after.  In other news, I've made a lot of progress on my 2.0 version of my HLV-6A 'Warthog' Duna cargo lander.  What you see in the picture is 316 parts, but that will fluctuate as I tweak and refine it.  The SRTG is the analogue to the FSPS, and the MPC is the analogue to the DIPS.  Even though the FSPS was supposed to be a proper fission reactor and the DIPS was supposed to be <abbr title="Radio-isotope Thermo-electric Generator (a.k.a. Mars rover heating device)">RTG</abbr>-powered, the SRTG is <abbr title="Radio-isotope Thermo-electric Generator (a.k.a. Mars rover heating device)">RTG</abbr>-powered and the MPC is purely solar.  The aft ramp drops and the SRTG repositions and plugs into the cargo lander to power the ISRU process, and the MPC can also do the same thing on the other side of the lander.

![HLV-6A%20Preview%20with%20Text_zps2ngqxc](http://i1356.photobucket.com/albums/q737/raptor_9000/Placeholder%20Photos/HLV-6A%20Preview%20with%20Text_zps2ngqxc9v.png)
